*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, by and through its employees, servants, and/or agents (collectively, “staff”), owed a duty to Plaintiff, as a business invitee, to use reasonable care to keep the Premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of any unreasonable dangers of which Defendant knew or should have known.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurrence focused on criticizing continued reliance on entrant classifications (trespasser/licensee/invitee). It does not itself articulate or affirm the specific duty owed to a business invitee to keep premises reasonably safe and to warn of dangers. While the full Mounsey decision is indeed a leading Massachusetts case on occupiers’ liability and invitee/licensee distinctions, this particular quoted portion does not clearly support the detailed duty statement in the proposition.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.raw_text: *Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass’n*, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 333, 336–37 (2010)
*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, by and through its employees, servants, and/or agents (collectively, “staff”), owed a duty to Plaintiff, as a business invitee, to use reasonable care to keep the Premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of any unreasonable dangers of which Defendant knew or should have known.
*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.case_name: Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condominium Association
*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the general Massachusetts rule that a property owner owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all lawful entrants, which includes maintaining the property in a reasonably safe condition. While the case does not use the specific term “business invitee,” it adopts the broad Mounsey duty to all lawful visitors and describes the owner’s obligation to maintain the premises safely and remedy hazards—substantively matching the duty language in the proposition. The duty to warn of unreasonable dangers is implicit in this general duty of reasonable care toward lawful entrants.
*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.relevant_excerpt: “A property owner ‘owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises.’ O’Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201, 204 (2000). ‘This duty includes an obligation to ‘maintain[] his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’’ Ibid., quoting from Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973).”

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and is within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3(a).proposition: Personal jurisdiction over Defendant is proper because Defendant is organized under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and/or regularly conducts business within Massachusetts, including operating the restaurant at the issue in Quincy, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Norfolk County Superior Court under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and/or related venue provisions, because the cause of action arose in Norfolk County, at Defendant’s restaurant located at 123 Main Street, Quincy, Massachusetts.

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Alternatively, and/or in addition, the hazardous condition existed for such a length of time that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied it, thereby establishing constructive notice.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the doctrine of constructive notice and acknowledges that a plaintiff may prove negligence by showing a foreign substance existed long enough that the defendant should have discovered and removed it. However, the court ultimately holds that, on the facts presented, there was insufficient evidence of the time element and orders judgment for the defendant. Thus, the case articulates the standard but finds it *not* satisfied; it does not support a proposition that constructive notice was established here, but rather the opposite.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt:
“In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present on the defendant’s premises for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.…

2. There was evidence in the instant case that the defendant’s employee… was on duty until 6 A.M. and the accident happened at 8:45 A.M.… There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required.…

Exceptions sustained. Judgment for the defendant.”

*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.raw_text: *Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961)
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.proposition: Alternatively, and/or in addition, the hazardous condition existed for such a length of time that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied it, thereby establishing constructive notice.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that, in the absence of evidence that defendant created the hazard or had actual notice, the plaintiff must prove the substance was on the floor long enough that defendant, using reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied it. The court then analyzes both the duration and the opportunity for discovery, and finds the evidence insufficient—thus affirming, but not satisfying, the constructive notice standard. This directly supports the legal proposition, even though the plaintiff ultimately lost on the facts.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.relevant_excerpt: “There was no evidence, however, that the dangerous condition was caused by a person for whose conduct the defendant was responsible or that the defendant’s employees knew of the condition. In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers.”

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: This duty of reasonable care includes the obligation to:   a. Use reasonable care to discover conditions that create an unreasonable risk of harm;   b. Make such conditions reasonably safe; and/or   c. Adequately warn invitees of such conditions.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the general premises-liability duty of a landowner to lawful visitors, including maintaining the premises in a reasonably safe condition and warning of dangers the owner knows or should know about. While the case ultimately finds no duty regarding alterations to the state highway, its articulation of the landowner duty aligns with the proposition that reasonable care includes discovering dangerous conditions, making them safe, and/or warning invitees.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 M.proposition: This duty of reasonable care includes the obligation to:   a. Use reasonable care to discover conditions that create an unreasonable risk of harm;   b. Make such conditions reasonably safe; and/or   c. Adequately warn invitees of such conditions.
*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 M.support_reasoning: The quoted concurring opinion does not articulate a general duty to use reasonable care to discover hazardous conditions, make them safe, or warn invitees. Instead, it concludes that the risk of injury from negligent operation of another vehicle at a self-service station is inherent and obvious, and expressly states there is no duty to warn of such a danger. That is the opposite of establishing an obligation to warn under these circumstances, so this excerpt does not support the claimed proposition.
*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 M.relevant_excerpt: "In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger."

*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.proposition: A business owner is liable for injuries caused by a dangerous condition on its premises where it:   a. Created the condition;   b. Had actual knowledge of the condition; or   c. Had constructive knowledge because the condition existed for such a length of time that, in the exercise of reasonable care, it should have been discovered and remedied.
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies premises-liability rules to a business visitor and expressly frames the plaintiff’s right to recover on whether the store, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed the foreign substance. The court notes there is no evidence the defendant created the condition or had actual knowledge, and therefore analyzes liability solely on constructive notice based on the length of time and visibility of the dangerous condition. This aligns with the proposition that liability can rest on creation, actual knowledge, or constructive knowledge after a reasonable time to discover and remedy the hazard.
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “There is no evidence that the ice cream was there through the acts of any persons for whose conduct the defendant was responsible… Likewise there was no evidence that the defendant or any of its employees knew of the presence of this ice cream… The plaintiff’s right to recover therefore depends upon evidence from which the jury could find that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed this foreign substance… Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it.”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized that slippery floors, including those made wet by water or other substances, can constitute an unreasonably dangerous condition when not properly addressed by the property owner.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly equates snow and ice hazards with other dangerous conditions such as a banana peel on a floor, and holds that property owners owe the same duty of reasonable care to address them. The court expressly recognizes that accumulations of snow and ice can be "dangerous conditions" or "defects" on property and that owners may be liable when they fail to exercise reasonable care to protect lawful visitors. This squarely supports the proposition that slippery surfaces made wet or icy can constitute unreasonably dangerous conditions if not properly addressed.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards... If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.

*Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc.*, 454 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized that slippery floors, including those made wet by water or other substances, can constitute an unreasonably dangerous condition when not properly addressed by the property owner.
*Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc.*, 454 Ma.case_name: Boston Gas Co. v. Century Indemnity Co.
*Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc.*, 454 Ma.support_reasoning: This opinion is an insurance coverage and allocation case about long-tail environmental contamination and pro rata allocation among insurers. It does not address premises liability, slippery or wet floors, or what constitutes an unreasonably dangerous condition on property. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition about slippery floors being recognized as unreasonably dangerous conditions in Massachusetts.
*Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc.*, 454 Ma.relevant_excerpt: We answer the certified questions as follows with respect to the policies at issue. As to the first certified question, we respond that liability should be prorated. As to the second certified question, we respond by adopting the time-on-the-risk method of prorating liability in the absence of evidence more closely approximating the actual distribution of property damage.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60B.proposition: Under G.L. c. 231, § 60B and related statutes, negligence claims for bodily injury must be evaluated under traditional tort principles, including duty, breach, causation, and damages, all of which are present here.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Comparative negligence, if any, on the part of Plaintiff is governed by G.L. c. 231, § 85, which provides that a plaintiff may recover so long as her negligence, if any, is not greater than the total negligence of the defendant and that damages shall be diminished in proportion to the plaintiff’s negligence.

*Zeroulias v. City of Salem*, 384 Mass..proposition: Comparative negligence, if any, on the part of Plaintiff is governed by G.L. c. 231, § 85, which provides that a plaintiff may recover so long as her negligence, if any, is not greater than the total negligence of the defendant and that damages shall be diminished in proportion to the plaintiff’s negligence.
*Zeroulias v. City of Salem*, 384 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns Massachusetts income tax treatment of partnership losses and capital gains; it does not address tort law, negligence, or comparative negligence under G.L. c. 231, § 85. There is no discussion of standards for plaintiff recovery based on comparative negligence or proportional reduction of damages. The proposition about comparative negligence is therefore unrelated to and unsupported by this case.
*Zeroulias v. City of Salem*, 384 Mass..relevant_excerpt: Gross income for Massachusetts income tax purposes is the Federal gross income with modifications not relevant here. G. L. c. 62, § 2(a). Smith v. Commissioner of Revenue, 383 Mass. 139, 140 (1981). The taxpayers’ grievance… is that because the taxpayers sustained a loss on their investment, they should not be subject to a capital gains tax on the transaction…. In the circumstances, it was within the constitutional authority of the Legislature to impose a tax on the capital gain of $24,155 realized by the taxpayers.

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.proposition: Plaintiff did not assume the risk of Defendant’s negligence, and any alleged open and obvious nature of the condition does not relieve Defendant of its duty where, as here, it should have anticipated that lawful visitors would use the Hallway and could be harmed if reasonable steps were not taken to remedy the hazard or provide adequate warning.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that an open and obvious condition does not entirely relieve a landowner of duty where the owner can and should anticipate that lawful entrants will nonetheless encounter the danger and be harmed. The court explains that, although the danger here was open and obvious and negated a duty to warn, the defendants still owed a duty to remedy because they created and maintained the dangerous trampoline–pool configuration knowing visitors would use it and could be injured, rejecting any per se ‘assumption of risk’ bar under these facts.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.relevant_excerpt:
“A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ …

‘While the open and obvious doctrine may relieve the defendant of its duty to warn, the doctrine does not mean that the defendant can maintain its property “in an unreasonably unsafe condition as long as the unsafe condition is open and obvious.”’ … On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover from Defendant all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, together with interest and costs, pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B and other applicable law.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B\u20136C.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as provided by G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B–6C and other applicable statutes;
